children.name: Integration
children.description: Active engagement of refugees in their host countries, culturally, economically, and socially. It is the opposite of exclusion, isolation, and limbo life.

children.name: Cultural Integration
children.description: The refugee's ability to speak the local language and to embrace or to live in harmony with the values of the host country.

children.name: Social Integration
children.description: The refugee's ability to build a wide and deep social network in the host country, such as having friends and good relations with neighbors.

children.name: Economic Integration
children.description: The refugee's ability to be active in the job market in the host place/country.

children.name: Place
children.description: The physical, environmental, and geographical 'container' where a refugee (or any other person) lives, acts, resides, or passes through, and [the place is] the idea or abstract notion that a refugee refers to as a site of residence, home, or an anchor of culture. Place need not be material only. It is an immaterial entity (manifesting as perception of tradition, as memory, as a definer of identity, etc.) as much as a material entity or a physical site.

children.name: Host Place
children.description: The place where a refugee lives. It may refer to a nation-state, city, or a village.

children.name: Home Place
children.description: The place of origin from where refugees had fled. It can be a city, a village, or a nation-state.

children.name: Refugee Agency
children.description: The capability of refugees to act, to choose, to be as they believe that will serve their well-being the best. It is, in other words, to be autonomous.

children.name: High Agency
children.description: The high autonomy, capability, and power enjoyed by a refugee in a way that makes her, even relatively, able to carve out her fate and livelihood.

children.name: Low Agency
children.description: The weak autonomy, capability, and power of a refugee in a way that makes her unable to carve out her fate and livelihood.

children.name: Refugee Identity
children.description: The way a refugee defines herself; the sense of a self.

children.name: Attachment
children.description: Refugee's linkage to a place; to which extent a refugee is attached to a place as a part of her identity.

children.name: Host Attachment
children.description: Refugee's attachment to a place(s) that is related to or located in her host place/country.

children.name: Home Attachment
children.description: Refugee's attachment to a place(s) that is related to or located in her home.

children.name: Belonging
children.description: Refugee's linkage to a group; to which extent a refugee is self-identified as a member of a group (national, religious, ethnic, etc.).

children.name: Host Belonging
children.description: Belonging to a group(s) that resides or exists in the host country.

children.name: Home Belonging
children.description: Belonging to a group that resides in refugees' original country (home place).

children.name: Place Making
children.description: The way a refugee conceptualizes, understands, and struggles to form - by whatever means she has - a place where she lives or desires to live (for example, by decorating her house in a similar way to traditional houses in her home place, or by political activities to form a new government in home, etc.).

children.name: Host Making
children.description: Activities that are located physically in the refugee's host place or essentially related to it.

children.name: Home Making
children.description: Activities that are located physically in the refugee's home place or essentially related to it (even if the refugee lives remotely).

children.name: Reintegration
children.description: The ability of those who return to re-establish their lives in their countries of origin.

children.name: Economic Well Being
children.description: The ability of a returnee to be active in her home again economically and in the job market.

children.name: Social Capital
children.description: The social network, social capital, that a returnee has in her home.

children.name: Political Process
children.description: The ability of a returnee to enjoy a stable (at least) political environment in her home.

children.name: Transnationalism
children.description: Activities of refugees that link or bridge multiple places together, home and host. These activities or practices can be endorsed at the everyday level or in the long term.
